conclusion: Analyzing whether the difference in speed between objects A and B is continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t₁ based on the v-t graph.
In a velocity-time (v-t) graph, the vertical axis represents velocity (v), the horizontal axis represents time (t), and the curves show how the velocity of each object changes over time.
Curve A is the upper curve with greater velocity values, and Curve B is the lower curve.
The difference in speed between objects A and B at any time t is defined as v₁(t) - v₂(t), where v₁(t) is the velocity of object A at time t and v₂(t) is the velocity of object B at time t.
For the difference to be continuously increasing, the rate of change of velocity (acceleration) of object A must be greater than the rate of change of velocity of object B.
The slope of curve A appears to be steeper than the slope of curve B initially, and as time progresses, both curves begin to flatten and then decrease.

At t = 0, both objects start from rest (v = 0) and accelerate (positive slope). The slope of curve A is steeper than curve B initially, meaning A accelerates faster and the difference in speed is increasing at first.
Curve A reaches its maximum and begins decreasing earlier than curve B. When curve A's slope becomes less than curve B's slope, the difference stops increasing.
Initially, the difference increases as A accelerates faster, but at some point before t₁, curve A's slope becomes less than curve B's slope, and the difference in speeds would start decreasing.

No, the difference in speed between the two objects is not continuously increasing throughout the time interval from 0 to t₁. The difference increases initially when object A accelerates faster than object B, but when object A's velocity begins to decrease more rapidly than object B's, the difference in speed begins to decrease.
